nl: If $f$ is defined on $E$, the graph of $f$ is the set of points $(x, f(x))$, for $x \in E$. In particular, if $E$ is a set of real numbers, and $f$ is real-valued, the graph of $f$ is a subset of the plane. Suppose $E$ is compact, and prove that $f$ is continuous on $E$ if and only if its graph is compact.
lean:
∀ (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (E : Set ℝ)
  (G : Set (ℝ × ℝ))
  (h₁ : IsCompact E)
  (h₂ : G = {(x, f x) | x ∈ E}), ContinuousOn f E ↔ IsCompact G
candidate: ∀ {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [CompactSpace X] (f : X → Y) : Continuous f ↔ IsClosed { x, X × Y | (x.fst, f x.fst) = x }
imports:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators
